thread.title: Teen admits spate of stolen, burnt-out vehicles across Nelson region
thread.title_full: Teen admits spate of stolen, burnt-out vehicles across Nelson region

author: Jonathan Carson
title: Teen admits spate of stolen, burnt-out vehicles across Nelson region
text:
Teen admits spate of stolen, burnt-out vehicles across Nelson region JONATHAN CARSON Last updated 17:15, February 7 2017 Alden Williams/Fairfax NZ 
A burnt-out Toyota vehicle at Appleby Reserve in May, 2015. 
The teens who left a trail of stolen and burnt-out cars across the Nelson region were caught out by video footage they took of their months-long crime spree. 
Since June last year, the pair have stolen, burnt-out, thieved from or interfered with at least 18 separate vehicles, racking up more than $85,000 worth of destruction and stolen goods. 
Levi Jensen McMaster, 19, pleaded guilty in the Nelson District Court on Tuesday to 27 charges related to stealing cars, setting them on fire, theft, and breaches of release conditions. 
The burnt-out Holden Crewman that was stolen from Mapua and dumped in Marahau. 
They include four charges of theft of a vehicle, three of arson, eight of theft from a car, two of theft, and six of unlawfully interfering with a vehicle. 
His friend and co-defendant has yet to enter a plea and, therefore, cannot be named. 
According to court documents, police had suspected McMaster and his associate were responsible for a spate of vehicle-related crime across the Nelson region as there was a pattern to the offending. 
In the 11 months before McMaster and his associate were arrested in early December, police said about 329 vehicles had been stolen across the region â€” almost one a day. A police photograph of Levi McMaster, released in June 2015 when he was wanted for allegedly stealing a vehicle. 
In October last year, police searched the house of McMaster's associate and seized three cellphones. 
The phones contained video footage, audio and photographs of the damaged and burnt-out vehicles, including one clip showing McMaster driving a stolen car and his associate, who was filming, calling him "Levi". 
For police, it was a smoking gun. 
Police were able to link McMaster and his associate to several vehicle thefts, putting an end to their relentless offending. 
In one of their most costly crimes, McMaster and his associate stole an unlocked Holden Crewman, worth $20,000, from Iwa St, Mapua, on October 6. 
The cargo area of the ute, owned by a builder, also contained about $20,000 worth of tools. 
McMaster or his associate drove the ute while the other followed in the associate's vehicle. They went through Motueka where they were captured on CCTV and continued to Marahau. 
They crashed the ute through a fence into a remote paddock where they did burnouts on the grass. 
They then positioned the front of the ute up against a fence post and revved the engine aggressively until one of the rear tyres exploded. 
They backed the ute into the middle of the paddock and set it on fire. 
McMaster and his associate also targeted neighbourhoods in Wakefield and Mapua, rummaging through cars and stealing money, tools, cycling gear and an iPod. 
Half of the $87,356 in reparation is being sought from McMaster. 
He has been in custody since he was arrested and appeared in court via audio-visual link. 
His sentencing is scheduled for March 13. 
CRIME SPREE TIMELINE 
June 7, 2016 
McMaster and associate steal Toyota Corolla from Hampden St, Nelson. It was found burnt-out and abandoned at Sharlands Creek. McMaster's cellphone was found at the scene. Photos on the phone show the vehicle on fire. Cost: $4200. 
September 6 
VW Golf GTA, worth $36,000 stolen from Martin St, Monaco. The vehicle was targeted as they had obtained an ignition key. They drove it on rocks at a riverbank in Appleby, causing panel damage. McMaster was seen on video doing burnouts in the car. They put the car in neutral and a rock on the accelerator, causing the wheels to spin before setting it on fire. Cost: $36,000 
September 20-21 
McMaster and associate drove to Wakefield. They unlawfully entered seven vehicles in driveways and on the street in Lord Rutherford St, stealing various items. They stole a Subaru Leone, worth $1500, that was unlocked and had its keys in the ignition. They drove it to Clover Road West in Appleby where they siphoned petrol from it into McMaster's associate's car. One of them drove it over large rocks into the middle of the river and set it on fire using petrol as an accelerant. Cost: $4000. 
October 5-6 
The pair went to Mapua and meddled with nine vehicles, including two boats. They stole various items before taking a $20,000 Holden Crewman loaded with $20,000 worth of tools. They drove it to Marahau where they did burnouts in a paddock and set it on fire. 
November 18-19 
Walking alone in Lynwood Tce, Nelson, McMaster stole an iPod and coins from an unlocked Nissan Pulsar parked in a driveway. Cost: $106. - Stuff
